criteria: Understanding of Similarity and Side Ratios
descriptions: Student does not demonstrate understanding of similarity in right triangles or side ratios.
Student shows limited understanding of similarity and its relation to side ratios in right triangles.
Student demonstrates partial understanding of similarity and side ratios, but struggles to connect the concepts.
Student understands similarity and side ratios and can generally explain their relationship in right triangles.
Student demonstrates a strong understanding of similarity and side ratios, clearly explaining their relationship and providing examples.
Student demonstrates comprehensive understanding of similarity and side ratios, clearly explaining their relationship, providing sophisticated examples, and extending the concept to novel situations.
Student cannot define trigonometric ratios (sine, cosine, tangent).
Student can identify trigonometric ratios but cannot accurately define them.
Student provides definitions for trigonometric ratios, but the definitions are incomplete or contain inaccuracies.
Student accurately defines sine, cosine, and tangent in terms of side ratios in a right triangle.
Student accurately defines sine, cosine, and tangent and explains their relationships to each other and the angles of a right triangle.
Student provides precise definitions of trigonometric ratios and explains their relationships, including reciprocal functions, and connects them to the unit circle.
Student cannot apply trigonometric ratios to solve problems involving right triangles.
Student attempts to use trigonometric ratios but struggles to set up the problem correctly.
Student can set up some problems using trigonometric ratios but makes errors in calculations or identifying correct ratios.
Student can solve basic problems involving right triangles using trigonometric ratios with minimal errors.
Student can solve a variety of problems involving right triangles using trigonometric ratios, demonstrating accuracy and efficiency.
Student can solve complex problems involving right triangles, including multi-step problems and real-world applications, using trigonometric ratios and providing clear justifications.
